questions.question_text: Where can an administrator see a visual overview of network connections between different VMs and different networks, within the NSX domain?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
NSX Intelligence provides a visual overview of network connections within the NSX domain, allowing administrators to see the traffic flows between different VMs and networks. It offers detailed visibility into network traffic patterns, application dependencies, and security posture, making it a valuable tool for monitoring and troubleshooting within NSX environments.

questions.question_text:
An NSX administrator is troubleshooting a connectivity issue with virtual machines running on an ESXi transport node.
Which feature in the NSX UI shows the mapping between the virtual NIC and the hostâ€™s physical adapter?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D- As in the official 4.1.x guide

questions.question_text: What are the four types of role-based access control (RBAC) permissions? (Choose four.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDEF
In addition to different authentication mechanisms, NSX Manager also
supports RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) to control the level of access to
the environment with the help of different roles. There are four levels of
access or permissions that can be assigned in NSX Manager as follows:
Full Access: Includes Create, Read, Update, Delete
Execute: Includes Read and Update
Read: Read-only access
None: No access

Selected Answer: B
Correct, as in the official vmware 4.1.X guide

questions.question_text: Which CLI command does an NSX administrator run on the NSX Manager to generate support bundle logs if the NSX UI is inaccessible?

choices.A: esxcli system syslog config logger set --id=nsxmanager

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct, as in the official vmware 4.1.X guide
